passage: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge: but fools despise wisdom and instruction.
moral: Respecting God is where learning starts. Wise kids listen and grow.
reflectionQ: When did you listen and learn well this week?
challenge: Ask one good question in class or at home today.

passage: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
moral: Guard what you think and feel; your heart guides your life.
reflectionQ: What is one thought you should keep out of your heart?
challenge: Replace one unkind thought with a kind one today.

passage: Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established.
moral: Give your plans to God, and He‚Äôll steady your thinking.
reflectionQ: What plan do you need to hand to God?
challenge: Pray one sentence over your homework before you start.

passage: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
moral: Good friends make each other better.
reflectionQ: Which friend helps you do the right thing?
challenge: Encourage one friend with a positive message.

passage: Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart, be acceptable in thy sight, O LORD, my strength and my redeemer.
moral: God hears your words and your thoughts. Aim to please Him.
reflectionQ: What words from today would please God?
challenge: Catch yourself once and change a rough word to a gentle one.

passage: Create in me a clean heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me.
moral: When we mess up, God can clean our hearts.
reflectionQ: What do you want God to clean from your heart?
challenge: Pray this verse slowly once today.

passage: I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills, from whence cometh my help. My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth.
moral: Real help comes from God.
reflectionQ: Where do you need God‚Äôs help right now?
challenge: Ask God for help before asking a person today.

passage: But they that wait upon the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary; and they shall walk, and not faint.
moral: Waiting on God brings new strength and courage.
reflectionQ: What are you waiting for God to do?
challenge: Take a quiet minute and breathe while you wait.

passage: Seek ye the LORD while he may be found, call ye upon him while he is near.
moral: Look for God now‚ÄîHe is close.
reflectionQ: How will you seek God today?
challenge: Read a verse and ask one question about it.

passage: He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the LORD require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?
moral: Do right, love kindness, and stay humble with God.
reflectionQ: What‚Äôs one humble choice you can make today?
challenge: Do one secret kind act without telling anyone.

passage: Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.
moral: By the way you live, you can lead others toward goodness and truth.
reflectionQ: Where can you shine this week?
challenge: Choose one helpful thing to do at home today.

passage: But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
moral: Put God first; He takes care of the rest.
reflectionQ: What does ‚Äòfirst‚Äô look like in your day?
challenge: Pray before games or screen time today.

passage: Therefore all things whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them: for this is the law and the prophets.
moral: Treat others the way you want to be treated.
reflectionQ: How do you want others to treat you?
challenge: Go first in kindness during a disagreement.

passage: Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.
moral: Jesus gives rest when you‚Äôre tired inside.
reflectionQ: What makes your heart tired?
challenge: Tell Jesus one worry before bed tonight.

passage: Jesus said unto him, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.
moral: Love God sincerely, not just outwardly.
reflectionQ: How can you love God with your mind today?
challenge: Memorize half of this verse by tonight.

passage: And the second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.
moral: Love people like you love yourself.
reflectionQ: Who needs your care today?
challenge: Share a snack or give a honest compliment.

passage: He that is faithful in that which is least is faithful also in much: and he that is unjust in the least is unjust also in much.
moral: God notices how faithfully we act in even the 'least' things.
reflectionQ: What small job can you do faithfully today?
challenge: Finish a small task carefully without reminders.

passage: But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name.
moral: Receiving Jesus makes you part of God‚Äôs family.
reflectionQ: What does being God‚Äôs child mean for you?
challenge: Thank God that He calls you His child.

passage: Then said Jesus to those Jews whivh believed on him, If ye continue in my word, then are ye my disciples indeed; And ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free.
moral: Sticking with God‚Äôs Word leads to real freedom.
reflectionQ: When can you read the Bible this week?
challenge: Read five verses and tell one thing you learned.

passage: By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples, if ye have love one to another.
moral: People know you follow Jesus when you love others.
reflectionQ: How can your love point to Jesus today?
challenge: Do one loving action for someone who annoys you.

passage: If ye love me, keep my commandments.
moral: Loving Jesus shows up in obeying Him.
reflectionQ: Which command will you focus on today?
challenge: Obey the first time when a parent or teacher asks.

passage: But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalm, and is all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.
moral: God wants us to share His Word, beginning nearby and reaching farther.
reflectionQ: Who could you tell about Jesus this week?
challenge: Share one thing God did for you with a friend.

passage: For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.
moral: Don‚Äôt be ashamed of Jesus; His good news saves.
reflectionQ: When do you feel shy about your faith?
challenge: Wear or draw a small cross and explain it to someone.

passage: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
moral: Confess and believe‚ÄîJesus saves.
reflectionQ: What do you believe about Jesus?
challenge: Tell God in prayer that you believe in Jesus.

passage: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
moral: True growth starts with renewing your mind to match God's ways.
reflectionQ: What thought needs renewing today?
challenge: Replace one negative thought with a verse.

passage: Therefore, my beloved brethren, be ye stedfast, unmoveable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, forasmuch as ye know that your labour is not in vain in the Lord.
moral: Stand firm and keep doing God‚Äôs work.
reflectionQ: Where do you need to be steady this week?
challenge: Finish one chore without stopping or complaining.

passage: Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new.
moral: Real change heppens through Christ, not by our own doing.
reflectionQ: What ‚Äòold thing‚Äô do you want God to change?
challenge: Write one new-good habit you‚Äôll practice this week.

passage: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.
moral: God grows good fruit in you.
reflectionQ: Which fruit will you show today?
challenge: Pick one fruit (kindness, patience, etc.) and practice it.

passage: And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not.
moral: Don‚Äôt quit doing good; God rewards in time.
reflectionQ: Where do you feel like giving up?
challenge: Try one more time at something hard today.

passage: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: not of works, lest any man should boast.
moral: Salvation is God‚Äôs gift, not something we earn.
reflectionQ: What is a gift you‚Äôre thankful for from God?
challenge: Say ‚Äòthank You‚Äô to God for His grace in prayer.

passage: And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you.
moral: Be kind and forgive like God forgave you.
reflectionQ: Who needs your forgiveness today?
challenge: Say, ‚ÄúI forgive you,‚Äù if someone says sorry.

passage: Children, obey your parents in the Lord: for this is right.
moral: Obeying parents pleases God.
reflectionQ: What‚Äôs one thing you can do the first time you‚Äôre asked?
challenge: Do one task today without being reminded.

passage: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves. Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others.
moral: Think of others first and serve them.
reflectionQ: Who can you put first today?
challenge: Let someone else choose first once today.

passage: Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God. And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.
moral: Don‚Äôt worry‚Äîpray with thanks, and God brings peace.
reflectionQ: What will you thank God for while you pray?
challenge: Pray about one worry and say ‚Äòthank You‚Äô after.

passage: Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things.
moral: Choose what you think about‚Äîaim for good and pure.
reflectionQ: Which ‚Äògood thought‚Äô can replace a bad one today?
challenge: Write one ‚Äòtrue and lovely‚Äô thought on a sticky note.

passage: And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men.
moral: Work hard for God, not for attention.
reflectionQ: What job will you do ‚Äòheartily‚Äô today?
challenge: Do one task at 100% effort and joy.

passage: Rejoice evermore. Pray without ceasing. In every thing give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you.
moral: Joy, constant prayer, and thanks are daily habits.
reflectionQ: Which of these three will you practice first?
challenge: Do a 3√ó10 challenge: 10s rejoice, 10s pray, 10s thank.

passage: For God hath not given us the spirit of fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind.
moral: God replaces fear with power, love, and clear thinking.
reflectionQ: Where do you need a sound mind today?
challenge: Say this verse out loud when you feel afraid.

passage: Work hard so you can present yourself to God and receive his approval. Be a good worker, one who does not need to be ashamed and who correctly explains the word of truth.
moral: Believers are encouraged to study God‚Äôs Word carefully and earnestly.
reflectionQ: When will you study the Bible this week?
challenge: Look up the meaning of one hard Bible word.

passage: Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
moral: Faith trusts God even when we can‚Äôt see.
reflectionQ: What are you trusting God for?
challenge: Write one sentence about what you hope for in God.

passage: Let your conversation be without covetousness; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee.
moral: God never leaves His children.
reflectionQ: When did you feel God close to you?
challenge: Thank God for being with you at bedtime.

passage: If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him.
moral: Ask God for wisdom‚ÄîHe gives generously.
reflectionQ: What do you need wisdom for today?
challenge: Pray for wisdom before starting a tough task.

passage: Wherefore, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath.
moral: Listen first, speak carefully, control anger.
reflectionQ: When is it hardest for you to listen?
challenge: Count to three before answering someone today.

passage: But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.
moral: Don‚Äôt just hear God‚Äôs Word‚Äîdo it.
reflectionQ: What will you do with what you learned today?
challenge: Write one action step after reading a verse.

passage: Casting all your care upon him; for he careth for you.
moral: Give your worries to God‚ÄîHe cares.
reflectionQ: What care will you hand to God right now?
challenge: Write your worry on paper and pray over it.

passage: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.
moral: Confess, and God forgives and cleanses.
reflectionQ: What do you need to confess to God?
challenge: Tell God you‚Äôre sorry for one wrong today.

passage: Beloved, let us love one another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God.
moral: Love flows from God to us and through us.
reflectionQ: Who needs your love this week?
challenge: Do one loving act for a classmate today.

passage: So God created human beings in his own image. In the image of God he created them; male and female he created them.
moral: You are made in God‚Äôs image‚Äîvaluable and loved.
reflectionQ: How will you respect God‚Äôs image in others?
challenge: Say something respectful to someone different from you.

passage: You intented to harm me, but God intented it all for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives.
moral: God can turn bad plans into good outcomes.
reflectionQ: Where do you want to trust God‚Äôs plan?
challenge: Tell God one hard thing and ask Him to use it for good.

passage: Honour your father and mother. Then you will live a long, full life in the land the LORD your God is giving you.
moral: Honor at home brings blessing.
reflectionQ: How can you show honor today?
challenge: Say ‚Äòyes, mom/dad‚Äô and do it cheerfully once.

passage: Be determined and confident. Do not be afraid of them. Your God, the LORD himself, will be with you. He will not fail you or abandon you.
moral: God won‚Äôt leave you‚Äîbe brave.
reflectionQ: What brave thing will you try with God today?
challenge: Write ‚ÄòGod is with me‚Äô on a small note you carry.

passage: And if it seem evil unto you to serve the LORD, choose you this day whom ye will serve; whether the gods which your fathers served that were on the other side of the flood, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land ye dwell: but as for me and my house, we will serve the LORD.
moral: Serving God is a daily choice.
reflectionQ: How will you choose God today?
challenge: Do one service act for your family tonight.

passage: But the LORD said unto Samuel, Look not on his countenance, or on the height of his stature; because I have refused him: for the LORD seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the LORD looketh on the heart.
moral: God cares most about your heart, not your looks.
reflectionQ: What does God see in your heart today?
challenge: Do a kind act no one else notices.

passage: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
moral: God leads and provides; you can rest in Him.
reflectionQ: Where do you need God‚Äôs guidance?
challenge: Pray ‚ÄòShepherd, lead me‚Äô before a chore today.

passage: O taste and see that the LORD is good: blessed is the man that trusteth in him.
moral: Try trusting God; you‚Äôll see His goodness.
reflectionQ: How did you see God‚Äôs goodness this week?
challenge: Tell someone one good thing God did for you.

passage: Hatred stirs up quarrels, but love makes up for all offenses.
moral: Hate brings fights; love brings peace.
reflectionQ: How can love calm a problem around you?
challenge: Use a gentle word when you feel annoyed.

passage: Even children are known by the way they act; whether their conduct is pure and right.
moral: Your actions show who you are becoming.
reflectionQ: What do your actions say about you today?
challenge: Choose one action that shows kindness or honesty.

passage: We all, like sheep, have gone astray, each of us turning to our own way. And the LORD has laid on him the iniquity of us all.
moral: We wander, but Jesus took our sin.
reflectionQ: What does it mean that Jesus carried your sin?
challenge: Thank Jesus for bearing your sins and loving you.

passage: For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, throughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end.
moral: God‚Äôs plans for you are good.
reflectionQ: What good future do you hope for with God?
challenge: Write one hope and pray over it.

passage: Trust in the LORD with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding. In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths.
moral: Give your whole trust to God and let Him guide you.
reflectionQ: Where do you need God to direct your path this week?
challenge: Pray one sentence asking God to guide a choice today.

passage: The liberal soul shall be made fat: and he that watereth shall be watered also himself.
moral: When you refresh others, God refreshes you.
reflectionQ: Who could you ‚Äòwater‚Äô with kindness today?
challenge: Share or help someone without being asked.

passage: Some people hurt others with their words, but the words of the wise bring healing.
moral: Sharp words hurt; wise words heal. Speaking with wisdom promotes peace and builds trust.
reflectionQ: Which words today could heal someone?
challenge: Replace one harsh word with a gentle one.

passage: Death and life are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
moral: Your words carry power‚Äîuse them for life.
reflectionQ: What life-giving words can you say today?
challenge: Give one sincere compliment before bedtime.

passage: He that covereth his sins shall not prosper: but whoso confesseth and forsaketh them shall have mercy.
moral: Hiding or ignoring wrongdoing prevents growth and blessing, but acknowledging mistakes and turning away from them leads to forgiveness and favor.
reflectionQ: Is there anything you should confess to God?
challenge: Tell God you‚Äôre sorry for one wrong and turn from it.

passage: Learn to do well; seek judgment, relieve the oppressed, judge the fatherless, plead for the widow.
moral: Learn to do good and help people in need.
reflectionQ: Who needs help that you could stand up for?
challenge: Do one small act for someone who needs support.

passage: Thou wilt keep him in perfect peace, whose mind is stayed on thee: because he trusteth in thee.
moral: Fixing your mind on God brings steady peace.
reflectionQ: What helps you keep your mind on God?
challenge: Pause 30 seconds and think on a promise of God.

passage: Don't be afraid, I am with you. Don't be discouraged, for I am your God. I will strengthen you and help you. I will hold you up with my victorious right hand.
moral: God is with you and gives strength‚Äîdon‚Äôt be afraid.
reflectionQ: Where do you need God‚Äôs strength today?
challenge: Say this aloud once: ‚ÄúGod is with me.‚Äù

passage: Call to me and I will answer you, and  will tell you great and unsearchable things you do not know.
moral: God invites us to communicate with Him through prayer. When we seek Him, He reveals insights, guidance, and blessings beyond our understanding.
reflectionQ: What question will you bring to God today?
challenge: Pray this verse once and ask boldly.

passage: The steadfast love of the LORD never ceases; His mercies never come to an end; they are new every morning; great and abundant is Your faithfulness.
moral: God‚Äôs mercy is new each morning‚ÄîHe never quits on you.
reflectionQ: What new mercy did you notice today?
challenge: Thank God for one fresh mercy at breakfast.

passage: If it be so, our God whom we serve is able to deliver us from the burning fiery furnace, and He will deliver us out of your hand, O king.
moral: God is able to rescue‚Äîtrust Him in pressure.
reflectionQ: What hard thing do you need courage for?
challenge: Say, ‚ÄúGod is able,‚Äù when you feel pressure.

passage: Now when Daniel knew that the writing was signed, he went into his house; and his windows being open in his chamber toward Jerusalem, he kneeled upon his knees three times a day, and prayed, and gave thanks before his God, as he did aforetime.
moral: Build strong prayer habits like Daniel.
reflectionQ: When can you set a daily time to pray?

passage: But I say, love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you.
moral: Jesus calls you to love and pray for even unkind people.
reflectionQ: Who is hard for you to love right now?

passage: Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you.
moral: Keep asking, seeking, and knocking‚ÄîGod hears.
reflectionQ: What will you ask, seek, and knock for this week?
challenge: Write down one prayer and check it in a week.

passage: Then said Jeus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
moral: Following Jesus means saying ‚Äòno‚Äô to self and ‚Äòyes‚Äô to Him.
reflectionQ: What choice can you make to follow Jesus today?

passage: Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.
moral: Jesus sends us to share the good news with everyone.
reflectionQ: Who could you tell about Jesus this month?
challenge: Invite a friend to church or kids‚Äô group.

passage: And he sat down, and called the twelve, and saith unto them, If any man desire to be first, the same shall be last of all, and servant of all.
moral: True greatness is not about power or status, but about serving others.
reflectionQ: Where can you serve at home or school?

passage: For even the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
moral: Jesus' ultimate act of service was giving His life for humanity, demonstrating true selflessness.
reflectionQ: How can you serve like Jesus this week?
challenge: Choose one person and do a Christ-like service.

passage: A good person produces good things from the good stored in their heart. An evil person produces evil things from the evil stored in their heart. What you say flows from what is in your heart.
moral: Your mouth reveals what fills your heart.
reflectionQ: Does my heart guide me to speak and act with kindness?
challenge: Before speaking, ask, ‚ÄúIs this kind and true?‚Äù

passage: Give, and you will receive. Your gift will return to you in full; pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, running over, and poured into your lap. The measure you use for others is the measure God will use for you.
moral: Give generously‚ÄîGod measures back with grace.
reflectionQ: Where could you give time or things today?
challenge: Give away one item you like to someone who needs it.

passage: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
moral: Jesus, the Word, is fully God from the start.
reflectionQ: What does it mean that Jesus is God‚Äôs Word?
challenge: Read John 1:1‚Äì5 and note one thing about Jesus.

passage: Jesus wept.
moral: Jesus cares deeply‚ÄîHe understands tears.
reflectionQ: Who needs comfort that you can show care to?
challenge: Send a kind message to someone hurting.

passage: I am the vine, ye are the branches: He that abideth in me, and I in him, the same bringeth forth much fruit: for without me ye can do nothing.
moral: Stay connected to Jesus to bear good fruit.
reflectionQ: How can you ‚Äòstay connected‚Äô to Jesus today?
challenge: Take 5 minutes to read and pray before homework.

passage: In everything I did, I showed you that by this kind of hard work we must help the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus, how he himself said, 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'
moral: Giving brings a deeper joy than getting.
reflectionQ: What could you give today‚Äîtime, help, or things?
challenge: Give first today before you ask for anything.

passage: For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God.
moral: Everyone makes mistakes, and we need to recognize our need for God's grace.
reflectionQ: What mistakes can i say sorry to God for today?

passage: For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
moral: Sin pays death, but God gives life in Jesus.
reflectionQ: Why is eternal life called a gift?
challenge: Explain this verse to a friend in your own words.

passage: Do all that you can to live in peace with everyone.

reflectionQ: Where can you choose peace instead of arguing?
challenge: Use one peacemaking sentence in a tense moment.

passage: Don't you realize that in a race everyone runs, but only one person gets the prize? So run to win.
moral: Run your race to win‚Äîgive God your best.
reflectionQ: What would ‚Äòyour best‚Äô look like today?
challenge: Do a task all the way with focus‚Äîno shortcuts.

passage: You must each decide in your heart how much to give. And don't give reluctantly or in response to pressure. 'For God loves a person who gives cheerfully.'
moral: God loves it when giving comes with a happy heart.
reflectionQ: How can you give cheerfully, not grudgingly?
challenge: Give something today and smile while you do.

passage: Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good to the use of edifying, that it may minister grace unto the hearers.
moral: Use words that build people up, not tear down.
reflectionQ: Who can you build up with words today?
challenge: Give two encouraging sentences to two people.

passage: Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.
moral: Suit up with God‚Äôs armor to stand strong.
reflectionQ: Which piece of armor do you need most today?
challenge: Name the six pieces out loud once today.

passage: I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.
moral: Keep moving toward Jesus‚Äô goal for you.
reflectionQ: What ‚Äòmark‚Äô are you pressing toward this week?
challenge: Work 10 more focused minutes on something hard.

passage: Let your speech be always with grace, seasoned with salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer every man.
moral: Let your words inspire and comfort, not wound or discourage.
reflectionQ: How can you ‚Äòseason‚Äô your words today?
challenge: Before speaking, think: ‚ÄúIs it gracious?‚Äù

passage: All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness.
moral: The Scripture shapes our character and guides us to live rightly.
reflectionQ: Which part of Scripture helps you the most?
challenge: Write one way the Bible corrected you this week.

passage: Show yourself in all respects to be a model of good works, and in your teaching show integrity, seriousness, and soundness of speech that cannot be condemned.
moral: Be an example others can follow.
reflectionQ: What good work could others copy from you today?
challenge: Do one ‚Äòpattern‚Äô act: helpful, honest, humble.

passage: For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.
moral: God‚Äôs Word is alive and has the power to transform.
reflectionQ: When did a verse ‚Äòcut‚Äô you in a good way?
challenge: Read one verse slowly three times today.

passage: And let us consider one another to provoke unto love and to good works.
moral: Think of ways to spur others on to love and good deeds.
reflectionQ: Who can you ‚Äòprovoke‚Äô to good today?
challenge: Send one encouragement to help someone do good.

passage: Therefore, since we are surrounded by such a huge crowd of witnesses to the life of faith, let us strip off every weight that slows us down, especially the sin that so easily trips us up. And let us run with endurance the race God has set before us.
moral: Run your race with patience‚Äîdon‚Äôt quit.
reflectionQ: Where do you need patience in your race?
challenge: Stick with one task five extra minutes today.

passage: Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
moral: Say yes to God and no to temptation.
reflectionQ: What temptation do you need to resist?
challenge: When tempted, say out loud: ‚ÄúNo. I belong to Jesus.‚Äù

passage: But as he which hath called you is holy, so be ye holy in all manner of conversation.
moral: God is holy‚Äîlet your whole life reflect Him.
reflectionQ: What part of your conduct needs to change?
challenge: Choose one habit to clean up this week.

passage: As every man hath received the gift, even so minister the same one to another, as good stewards of the manifold grace of God.
moral: God gave you gifts to help, uplift, and support others.
reflectionQ: What gift can you use to help someone today?
challenge: Use one talent to bless a family member.

passage: My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue; but in deed and in truth.
moral: Real love shows up in actions and truth.
reflectionQ: What loving action can you do today?
challenge: Do one loving deed without being asked.

passage: Behold, I stand at the door, and knock: if any man hear my voice, and open the door, I will come in to him, and will sup with him, and he with me.
moral: Jesus invites you‚Äîopen your heart to Him.
reflectionQ: How can you ‚Äòopen the door‚Äô to Jesus today?
challenge: Spend two quiet minutes talking to Jesus.

passage: But his delight is in the law of the LORD; and in his law doth he meditate day and night.
moral: Love God‚Äôs Word and think on it often.
reflectionQ: When can you meditate on a verse today?
challenge: Repeat one verse three times during the day.

passage: Delight thyself also in the LORD; and he shall give thee the desires of thine heart.
moral: When you delight in God, your desires begin to relfect His will.
reflectionQ: What desire will you place before God?
challenge: Tell God one desire and ask Him to shape it.

passage: Cast thy burden upon the LORD, and he shall sustain thee: he shall never suffer the righteous to be moved.
moral: Give your worries and burdens to God instead of handling them alone.
reflectionQ: What burden will you cast on God today?
challenge: Write your worry and pray, then throw the paper away.

passage: So teach us to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto wisdom.
moral: Life is short‚Äîuse your time with wisdom.
reflectionQ: What is the wisest thing you can do today?
challenge: Plan your next hour and stick to it well.

passage: How can a young person stay on the path of purity? By living according to your word.
moral: Pay attention to God‚Äôs Word to stay clean.
reflectionQ: What verse will you obey today?
challenge: Choose one verse and do what it says.

passage: Study this Book if Instruction continually. Meditate on it day and night so you will be sure to obey everything written in it. Only then will you prosper and succeed in all you do.
moral: Speak and think on God‚Äôs Word to walk in success His way.
reflectionQ: When will you read and talk about God‚Äôs Word today?
challenge: Share one verse with a family member tonight.
